Article.ArticleTitle: Coordination Chemistry of the Antimony(III) and Bismuth(III) Cations using Bis(α-iminopyridine) as Ligand.

AbstractText: Bis(alpha-iminopyridine) L has been employed as the redox non-innocent Schiff-base ligand to coordinate with cationic antimony(III) and bismuth(III) centers. Mono- and di- cationic compounds: [LSbCl<sub>2</sub> ][CF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> ] 1, [LBiCl<sub>2</sub> ][CF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> ] 2, [LSbCl<sub>2</sub> ]<sub>2</sub> [Sb<sub>2</sub> Cl<sub>8</sub> ] 3, [LBiCl<sub>2</sub> ]<sub>2</sub> [Bi<sub>2</sub> Cl<sub>8</sub> ] 4, [LSbCl][CF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> ]<sub>2</sub> 5, [LBiCl][CF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> ]<sub>2</sub> 6 have been isolated and characterized using single crystal X-ray crystallography in the solid-state and solution-state NMR studies. These compounds have been prepared from PnCl<sub>3</sub> (Pn=Sb, Bi) and chloride abstracting agent such as Me<sub>3</sub> SiCF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> or AgCF<sub>3</sub> SO<sub>3</sub> in the presence of L. The Bi tri-cationic species forms heteroleptic compound 7, being coordinated by two types of Schiff-base donors L and L'. The latter has been in situ generated by the cleavage of one of the two imines present in L.
